poem:
Crossing Borders

In the land of mist and rain,  
voices rise like smoke in autumn.  
A map unfolds with lines of ink,  
where journeys end and nations blend.  
But in the echo of a harbored cold,  
the sea keeps her secrets, tightly held,  
whispering tales of those who dared  
to sail beyond the paper's edge.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "More than 900 Labour figures decry party’s migration and asylum policy A group of more than 900 Labour members and trade unionists, including MPs and peers, have accused the government of copying the “performative cruelty” of the Conservatives in its migration and asylum policy. In a joint statement, they singled out the Home Office’s decision, revealed last week, to refuse citizenship to anyone who arrives in the UK via “a dangerous journey” such as a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
